As the population grows ever more sedentary, it is essential that we as nutritionists strive to make healthy lifestyle choices with our clients.
At the same time as there is a need to reduce our overall sedentary lifestyle and it's associated health problems, the number of people suffering from a heart attack and stroke is also doubling every year.

An NHS study indicates that the prevalence of cardiovascular conditions such as heart attack and stroke is increasing globally. Approximately 80% of adult populations is at increased risk of developing CVD in the next 15 years.

Heart Disease is the leading killer of both men and women. There is currently no effective treatment for the main causes of heart disease. Most sufferers are not aware of the risk factors which can develop into heart disease. We have identified that poor diet is amongst the most harmful to our health.

The risk factors for developing heart disease include poor intake of saturated fat, cholesterol and sodium which are known to increase arterial disease. There are additional risk factors linked to poor diet such as type 2 diabetes, hypertension, obesity & being overweight/obese, and smoking.

Diabetes is the most prominent risk factor in the UK today. The World Health Organization and the American Diabetes Association suggest a 14% reduction in the incidence of diabetes between 1980 and 2004.
The risk of developing diabetes in the UK is predicted to increase further in the coming years. The number of people already diagnosed with diabetes is expected to more than double by 2030.

The risk factors to the prevention of diabetes in the UK are as follows:-

• Being overweight.
• Being overweight/obese.
• Smoking.
• Having gestational diabetes and having type 1 diabetes (if you have them).
• Being diabetic, diabetic prediabetic or pre-diabetic

The NICE guidance describes high blood pressure as ‘a potentially modifiable risk factor that can be reduced by ‘lifestyle and other means’ in selected ethnic groups.’ As such, it is considered important to have this information in regard to his life history, especially if he lives in a country where a high percentage of the population has hypertension. One NICE panel member, Dr. Patrick J Clements, told me about a clinical trial with two hospitals in the US where 150 patients could be selected within 10 days and their blood pressure and serum homocysteine levels monitored over a period of 26 months. If these patients had already had a heart attack, the risk of heart attack was significantly lower without a low-risk cardiovascular risk and the risk of stroke if the participant had a history of a stroke or a previous heart attack.
That is an intriguing example of the ability of NICE guidelines to move toward evidence through a rigorous use of a data set and a process of cross-validation. And this does not just apply to the blood pressure: the NICE guideline for blood pressure noted above is the result of a rigorous review of population-level data in 4,977 elderly, non-fatal, white men and women in 21 European countries. The same population-wide data set was used in the 2008 study to predict whether or not a 60-year-old man with hypertension is at high-risk for a cardiovascular event (high-risk cardiovascular risk). A review of the 2008 study revealed that the prevalence of hypertension (as measured with validated instruments such as the Hamilton Hypertension Scale), stroke (using an adapted version of the Hamilton Strokes Index devised in Germany and widely used for screening and risk prediction), and death from cardiovascular causes could be estimated by the high-risk hypertension (HRA) category, or the presence of specific cardiovascular risk factors (as identified in the 2008 study), on a 0.05 level, without regard to the patient’s ethnicity.
It should be noted that the guidelines for CVD screening in the US are based on hypertension prevalence data in 75,000 patients from the 2006 NHANES and on the mortality data in 24,000 cancer and heart disease patients from the NHANES. A large panel of 589 US centers has been used for this study. If they are able to find an effect that is highly relevant and relevant for the US population based on the 2008 study, then the US population-wide data set could be used for subsequent follow-up studies, and it is possible – and most likely – that future trials like this could be published with the American Heart Association’s 2013 guidelines. And the same is not true if they are able to find no effect by chance.
What other interventions should be funded that may result in significant reductions in hypertension and strokes?
The 2009 guidelines that came out, the 2009 “Guidelines for Screening and the Management of High-Risk Cardiovascular Diseases” identified five interventions that could be used to decrease risks for cardiovascular disease. One of these initiatives, which was developed using the NHANES data set, was to use the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute’s definition of the Framingham Heart Study as a model for how to apply these five interventions to each of 12 different regions of the United States in which the risk of cardiovascular events were at or above 300%.
What other interventions could be used? There are a number of ways that could be applied that may lower the incidence of cardiovascular disease: using the Framingham data to develop a risk index for individuals with hypertension, limiting their high intake of saturated fats and keeping their cholesterol levels at more than 250 mg/dL, and stopping lifestyle modiﬁcations, such as smoking, if someone has a high or normal LDL-C level or smoking, and so on. There are also interventions that could be applied like a “dose-response” method, such as lowering your blood pressure to a level where you still feel the benefit of not having high-risk disease. And it would be good to explore the possibilities of a potential high-purity blood-thirsty drug as a potential intervention.

The best approach to avoid CVD is to do all you can to prevent it. Even if every little bit makes a difference, we can’t do it all. Therefore, there are many, many things you can do to prevent CVD—such as eating a heart-healthy diet, getting regular exercise, taking blood pressure medication, maintaining a healthy weight, reducing the amount of salt and fat in the diet, and reducing blood pressure to below 130/80 mmHg.
As we get older, we will need to make some changes in our lifestyles to prevent CVD. The best way to do this is to have an active lifestyle (exercise) and live a healthy lifestyle. So this is my plan:
- Eat a diet rich in unsaturated fats (vegetable oils, nuts, seeds, and oils)
- Eat lots of fruits, vegetables, whole grains, beans, and peas, and low-fat dairy products, nuts, and seeds
- Do moderate physical activity for at least 150 minutes per week and also to meet the minimum activity level (60 minutes per week, five days a week)
- Control or prevent high blood pressure by lowering your blood pressure to below 130/80 mmHg. If you have high blood pressure, your first step should be lowering the blood pressure to below 130/80 mmHg. Ask your healthcare provider how to do this when you are younger.
- Limit your daily intake of sodium, which is high in processed food and canned foods. Foods rich in potassium (potatoes, bananas, and yogurt) may not need to be restricted, but they should still be eaten with caution.
- Limit your intake of total fat, but only under the supervision of your healthcare provider.
- Keep it to less than 30% of your total calorie intake, such as 2500 kcal or less in men and 2000 kcal or less in women.
- Choose healthy fats from fish, nuts, seeds, and oils.
- Have a regular 7-day schedule for healthy snacking
There are other lifestyle changes you can make to reduce your risk of CVD as well:
- Avoid smoking;
- Maintaining a healthy weight;
- Exercising regularly to get a certain amount of daily physical activity;
- Reducing your intake of salt, such as eating smaller meals more frequently;
- Limiting your intake of total fat, including saturated fat, cholesterol, trans fat, and free fatty acids;
- Managing your blood sugar;
- Taking medications as prescribed
The main prevention strategy for CVD involves understanding your risk factors and being able to reduce or control those factors to lower your risk of CVD. You can get the most from your lifestyle with these strategies:
- Talk to your doctor about your risk of developing CVD;
- Follow advice you have received on your own from the healthcare team;
- Take action to limit your intake of fat and sodium in your diet;
- Avoid a high-fat diet that does not contain enough calories or potassium, a mineral found in fruits, vegetables, legumes, and nuts;
- Reduce your intake of sodium to less than 2000 mg per day.
- Limit your intake of total fats to less than 50 g per day or 50% more fat than you burn on a metabolic cycle.
- Limit your intake of saturated fats to less than 30 g per day or 20 g less than is in a 300 gram meal.
- Do not consume more than 2oz of red meat per day, or more than 2 small meals per day (6-8hrs each)
- Do not eat high-cholesterol foods such as red meat, eggs, and butter.
- Do no drink wine after dinner.
- Avoid using tobacco and smoking. Ask your doctor if it is OK to smoke when you are having dinner.
- Limit or avoid alcohol because alcohol has been found to raise the blood pressure of people who have CVD, and it can also affect the way HDL (the good cholesterol) and LDL (the bad cholesterol) work.
- Limit your intake of caffeine (found in coffee) and other sweetened beverages.
- Limit your intake of saturated and trans fats (found in meat, bacon’s, and other processed meats).
- Avoid excessive alcohol.

For people who have diabetes and no evidence of CVD, you would need to use two strategies for prevention: reducing blood pressure and increasing HDL cholesterol. You would recommend that John’s exercise and diet and lifestyle recommendations change over time. At that point, he would be recommended to start taking medication for hypertension.
For individuals with or at high risk of CVD who do not have evidence of CVD, you would have to change the strategy. You would recommend that John modify his diet and physical activity to prevent or manage the cardiovascular and systemic effects of the metabolic disorder, as well as make lifestyle changes to have an healthier blood lipid level.
This individual’s blood pressure would need to be lower than expected, or perhaps even lower than 125/80 mmHg. This would also include a reduction or decrease within the following parameters: total cholesterol below 200, HDL cholesterol below 40, blood sugar below 140, blood pressure below 130/80, and total weight below 150.

For individuals with a higher-than-normal weight and/or body mass index (BMI), you would recommend you change your exercise program and activity level to help manage blood pressure. For some people, these changes to lifestyle and medications will be enough to prevent type 2 diabetes, as well as the progression of the disease. However, you would suggest that someone with a higher-than-average BMI may have better control of their high cholesterol levels and, therefore, also better management of their type 2 diabetes risk.

How much can heart failure cause?
No one can say exactly how much, but in most patients with congestive heart failure the risk of death is 2-4 times greater than the risk of death from coronary heart disease in both healthy subjects and in patients with congestive heart failure. Heart failure occurs in all ages, but is one of the more common causes of death in elderly people and in patients who undergo heart surgery. The risk of death in elderly people with congestive heart failure increases by 31%.
How many people have died because of heart failure?
About 2-3 million people die each year as a result of heart failure and this figure is expected to increase as more and more people become afflicted by the disease.
Who is likely to develop heart failure and what are the risks?
Anyone who has a heart transplant, an artificial heart or a ventricular septal defect is at risk. People who suffer from diabetes, obesity or who have had heart surgery are also at risk of heart failure and their condition is more likely to become worse.
When will heart failure begin to develop?
The frequency of heart failure and the progression of symptoms varies from person to person. Some people can be affected every day, and others in 3-5 years. It may be that there is only gradual development and may not present any symptoms for many years before the diagnosis of heart failure has been made.
What are the symptoms of heart failure?
Symptoms of heart failure occur gradually over many years and may include shortness of breath, loss of appetite, fatigue, swollen ankles or legs, fever, weight loss or weight gain, swelling under the skin or in the neck, ears, throat and stomach, and shortness of breath or a heavy cough.
What do doctors think of people with heart failure and what is the risk of heart failure developing in them?
There is no cure for the condition but it is a serious issue. Heart failure can be mild or severe. Mild heart failure means that the patient is having symptoms but the treatment is not good. Sustained symptoms mean that the patient is not getting well. Severe heart failure means that the patient is having symptoms constantly from time to time. This can lead to sudden death if they do not know what to do to treat the problem. In these cases, it is important that it is treated by a specialist such as a cardiologist or pulmonologist.

Cardiovascular disease deaths are lower among older adults and people in countries with lower levels of smoking, says a review published in the BMJ. There is limited evidence on how and why the rates were falling, but some might be due to better treatment of cardiovascular diseases, more frequent screening, changes in tobacco smoke from the current ban on smoking, and restrictions of nicotine-containing products.
A meta-analysis published in the BMJ looked at the effect of changes in smoking status and/or cigarettes on heart disease in the general population, especially at all life stages. The study was a combination of randomised and nonrandomised trials and it showed that smoking can lower risk of heart disease but does not necessarily apply to older people and those with high levels of nicotine. The analysis also showed significant reductions in deaths and deaths were only partially attenuated for those with low or average smoking levels. Most deaths had occurred after age 75, 0-60 years, men and more than 25% of deaths were from coronary heart disease (CHD). The analysis showed that smoking cessation for at least 1 year is not likely to improve the outcomes of any health service.
In the UK, new recommendations to combat smoking, called a smoke withdrawal plan for treatment, had been put in place some years ago, but implementation remains largely lacking. In the US, the Department of Health and Human Services has established a smoking cessation program targeting smokers who want to quit. These are managed using the ICH-RFPQ-83, developed after 1980 to address smoking, nicotine and other tobacco products use by the population, and smoking causes and associated diseases.

"We have reviewed the literature and can conclude that we can use the recommendations in this guideline when prescribing antihypertensive therapy in patients with this common cause of CVD," said the director of the NICE guideline development unit, Jasmine Maudy, MRS. "At present, they focus on preventing heart attack and stroke, and the risk groups - hypertensive people, diabetics, and people that have a history of myocardial infarction. Our guidelines do not prescribe these drugs for people because of their increased risk. However, individuals with no or very low blood pressure, no history of MI, etc., may have a greater risk with hypertension, and they could benefit from treatment."
What is the role of a GP in prescribing antihypertensive therapy?
"When people are seeing a GP," said the NICE guideline development team, "they will usually recommend a "first-line" or'standard' dose of antihypertensives for them. However, most clinicians are only on prescribing 'trial' drugs that have little evidence of benefit and side effects, which is why we are seeing very high numbers of patients needing to be treated with alternative drugs as first-line prescriptions." In response to the increased use of antihypertensive regimens, such as valsartan, the NICE guidelines suggest using different medications or combinations, such as potassium citrate and sodium nitrate, to get blood pressure back to the target range.
Where are we now in prescribing antihypertensive medications for heart attack and stroke patients?
"In general, non-inferiority was reported in randomised controlled trials that we could find for hypertension in patients at high-risk of CV death. However, patients who are at risk of CV death cannot be appropriately targeted and are treated with medications at lower doses," explained Dr. Maudy. "Most of the non-inferiority was reported for either an initial initial dose of 5mg/kg e-buplets or 248mg e-buplets. However, the results are somewhat limited for a large number of patients. We cannot tell whether patients who choose to lower the initial dosage of e-buplets or e-buplets are more likely to get worse rather than better. Further studies are required, including a wider range of antihypertensive studies."
What are the implications of the recommendations for clinicians and the public?
"The recommendations in this guideline will be useful for clinicians as it provides the information needed to make a judgement call. They will be useful as part of a continuum of care - whether it is a patient with hypertension or a patient with a previous stroke," added Dr. Maudy. "This is why the guideline is based upon a large, robust scientific evidence base, not on patients' subjective preferences. The evidence base was supported by the British Hypertension Society's (BHS) guidelines. We need to see the evidence base on the effects of antihypertensive medication to develop appropriate guidance."
The advice from the NICE guidelines was accepted by the British Medical Association Scientific Committee by consensus on 10 June 2017.

Can they be adapted for Chinese patients and how might they work?
The first guideline we discussed was a recommendation for a standard weight control program for patients at high risk for cardiovascular disease that has been endorsed by experts. That included:
- A healthy lifestyle aimed at a reduction of waist circumference through weight reduction and physical activity
- Low-carbohydrate diets with a daily target consumption of about 50 grams of carbohydrates from all sources
- Fasting blood screening to determine whether patients meet the 70% target for CVD, or if it's needed at 50%
- A lifestyle assessment with an NICE-delivered physical fitness assessment
The second guideline was one addressing the importance of screening for cardiovascular disease early in the course of a patient's life (a family history of CVD or high triglyceride levels). This type of screening also might involve lifestyle changes or blood pressure or blood glucose testing depending upon individual circumstances. Some of the most appropriate lifestyle changes will probably include:
- Exercise - resistance training (strength and/or flexibility) on three to four days every week
- Low carbohydrate diets if necessary, and
- Healthy lifestyle choices, such as avoiding smoking and alcohol
- Weight loss if necessary
The third guideline was a high-intensity exercise plan - something of concern to many with a history of CVD in general. For patients with a history of CVD, such as those in the Chinese context, there is a need for a 20–30 minute workout on a daily basis to meet the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute's recommendation of 150–200 minutes of vigorous activity each week. Those who are in sufficient readiness as a model, or who have never met that number before, might not meet the guideline, and there are numerous reasons for that. However, if an individual has completed one or more high-intensity resistance training sessions in 3–10 weeks as well as any other exercise that has proven to be effective, then they're clearly moving closer to meeting the benchmark as they age.
The fourth guideline is an intervention program for individuals with hypertension to improve their blood pressure control while minimizing heart attacks and strokes. This was a group of people who would have had a 7.0 mm Hg systolic or diastolic pressure greater than or equal to 160/ 90 mm Hg before cardiovascular event prevention had been a principal goal. This patient population would most likely have benefitted from an intervention program and had an earlier CVD risk history. For such patients, there are several variables they must consider including:
- Having hypertension, smoking, and history of heart disease, or had a first cardiac event
- Regular physical exercise
- A BMI of ≥25 (low risk if BMI is between 20 and 25)
- A history of a family history of CVD (either a family member with a history or a relative)
- Cardiovascular risk measures, such as high family history, smoking, or history of hypertension
The fifth recommendation is for community-based primary care, specifically, for high-risk individuals > 60 years old, who are likely to have an increased CVD risk. The current guidelines for cardiopulmonary secondary care suggest recommending a 20-minute walk at least every third week. This suggests a 200-minute regimen, but we believe it's unlikely that 21-30 minutes would be sufficient for this population.
Finally, the sixth guideline was a lifestyle intervention program designed to improve the control and adherence to a low-fat diet and exercise program. In particular, we would recommend:
- Weight loss
- Reduced carbohydrate intake
- Stopping smoking
- Drinking less alcohol
- Exercise programs
- Healthy lifestyles (eating patterns, such as increasing in fruit and/or vegetables and being more physically active)
- Weight reduction & healthy diet. This is also the type of exercise that has the greatest benefit with long term results
- Regular doctor visits for evaluation & treatment if needed
- Monitoring for blood lipid levels and for cardiovascular disease
- Reducing the use of tobacco.
There are no major complications from these methods. For healthy people, a balanced lifestyle reduces their risk of CVD-related illnesses. However, the impact on CVD is usually modest. In general, we recommend that lifestyle changes be made as a strategy, rather than as an inevitable step in the course of any course of CVD prevention and control.

NICE guidelines define a number of conditions that can be ‘preventative’ or ‘protective’ of CVD, and these are described below. 25 different CVD conditions can be ‘preventative’ even in the most common cardiovascular disease in the world, i.e. high bad cholesterol, high blood pressure and insulin resistance. As a result some people with these heart conditions can dramatically lower their risk of dying from stroke or heart attack. Although an individual’s personal experience may not always match up with the results of these guidelines, this doesn’t stop people from taking action.
What exactly is the Framingham Framingham risk score (FRS)?
This scale was developed by the Framingham Research Foundation to classify risk scores for cardiovascular deaths. The first FRS described a person’s risk of dying within 1 year after their first birthday, using information from data from 38,513 males born in 1948 to 1948 from Framingham, Massachusetts, USA. These data are from almost 100,000 people before 1998.
The FRS uses two key variables to predict CVD risk that can be used independently to describe risk for a person. The first is the waist measurement, which helps classify people based on their ‘waist circumference’.
The second variable is cholesterol: a measure of a person’s ‘bad’ cholesterol. The FRS uses a score of 0 to 100 for LDL cholesterol, with 100 being borderline and 0 being perfectly healthy, and with a total cholesterol of less than 200 and an HDL cholesterol score below 40. Individuals without elevated risk scores and with a normal cholesterol and blood pressure are considered to be ‘normal’.
Who is in the UK?
The NHS will use all the research into the effects of these FRSs, and these results are published in the NHS’s ‘The Quality and Outcomes of Care Report’ 26. However, this has not been done for the 79 million people in the EU. The FRS is used only by the NHS to assess the efficacy of public health initiatives on lowering CVD risk and for evaluating the effectiveness of CVD treatments.
The NHS doesn’t directly use these FRSs in its ‘guidance on CVD prevention’, rather, it uses other data to assess their effectiveness in its ‘Prevent’ initiative, the largest UK-wide survey of people’s cardiovascular health. People with a low risk of CVD who are in the survey receive additional guidance. This means people are more likely to do the research needed to change how they live their lives, to help reduce CVD risk, including by using different lifestyle strategies, such as weight loss and exercise, and by taking other risk reductions, such as not smoking and reducing alcohol consumption.
More about the research is available here.
The 47 million NHS people don’t have a set of CVD-related guidelines in practice. What should follow if there are no CVD guidelines in place?
What we need to be clear about is that the aim of any CVD-related guidelines is to change the way the public is treated for CVD, and not restrict people from doing things which are very important to them.
This means not just treating CVD using traditional, prescribed medical measures, but also improving their lives not only through prevention but through their own decision-making. This is something known as the ‘contribution of decision-makers to improve mortality’ in the WHO and UKCDS 27.
Where can this be done with little or no impact on people’s lives?
In most cases, the NHS will give advice based on a range of available data and based on a more appropriate risk factor analysis (such as age or gender), taking into account factors such as income and education, as well as other factors. The aim is to improve lives in the general population, including to lower the burden of CVD.
In addition, decision-makers and people themselves are a vital part of the risk-reducing community, and so the NHS has a special role to play in identifying, implementing and monitoring people’s progress towards implementing the key objectives in its ‘Prevent’ program.
The NHS already makes a difference in many ways, but it is important not to forget that people also have a choice. The term "metabolic syndrome" refers to a combination of 4 conditions: abdominal obesity (obesity), high triglycerides, high systolic blood pressure and high LDL blood cholesterol. It is an important factor in the development of heart disease, the major cause of morbidity and mortality, and stroke.
Metabolic syndrome is also an important component of the metabolic syndrome (also called polyendocrine syndrome) in which many other diseases (diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hypercholesterolaemia or dyslipidaemia) are noted as well as an important part of the familial tendency to type 2 diabetes, renal or cardiovascular disease and osteoporosis.
Many of the features associated with metabolic syndrome, such as abnormal lipid measurements, a predisposition to hypertension and diabetes, and increased visceral fat deposition, occur in women. In many studies, such as the National Institutes of Health sponsored Nurses' Health Study of 1988-1992 and the Nurses Health Studies, the prevalence of metabolic syndrome is slightly lower among women than among men.
There are many possible causes of metabolic syndrome which are under study, not least of which is the presence of a genetic predisposition. The metabolic syndrome (or syndrome X) is thought to be triggered by an abnormal fat mass or the abnormal way fat is turned onto muscle. This causes too little protein in the diet and a reduction in the amount of physical activity.
There is also some suggestion that the increased level of insulin in humans and primates (in mice) causes this syndrome to develop, although it is unclear how the two factors, high levels of insulin induced by overweight humans, and high insulin production by body fat, contribute in any way.

Charter effect: When more people have been advised to make a healthy lifestyle choice, there is a higher likelihood of a change in the behaviour of those at a lower-risk. This makes it more likely that a person's heart disease risk will decrease with a change to their individual lifestyle. The likelihood of these individuals following the guidelines is increased in populations under-resourced, such as inner-city or resource-limited populations. For example, China, Hong Kong, and Macau have an exceptionally high burden of cardiovascular disease in comparison with many other high-income countries. There is a need to understand which health conditions are at high risk, and to provide the best service possible to each population at the level in which healthcare delivery is most likely to succeed. It is likely that the government will develop a special programme to provide these individuals with advice on reducing their risk of heart disease – however, this initiative will need to be developed and fully-funded, and would require the active involvement of government and other stakeholders.

Charter effect: When more people take part in an educational program, there is a greater chance of a change in the individual's behaviour. This means that the individual could be motivated to reduce their health risk, even if they lack the education they require to do so. For example, many individuals who have not completed a formal lifestyle-enhancement programme have adopted lifestyles such as not smoking, eating healthy, exercising regularly, and not drinking alcohol (BBC News, 2008; BBC News). If the government implemented the programme, it could produce the desired results. Although the programme requires government funding, it would be important to ensure that the programme is well-funded and that it is easily accessible to the public, thereby improving the likelihood that the programme will succeed.

Varying and systematic risks: There are many health conditions which may have multiple, systematic risks. For example, a person with diabetes at high risk for CVD is likely to have higher levels of blood pressure, and less consumption of carbohydrates than some of their closest friends who do not have diabetes. They also likely to be more sedentary and less physically active than their counterparts who do not have diabetes. They may also be more likely to be obese (BMI > 30) at high risk and to be non-smokers. This increases the likelihood of other outcomes such as heart disease, osteoporosis, and diabetes, and the chance that CVD will develop to a much greater degree than if the person had not yet achieved the systematic risks of these conditions.

The programme will also aim to influence health behaviour change, which may include various forms of behaviour modification, e.g. providing a reduction in physical activity, reducing intake of unhealthy food, and minimising consumption of unhealthy beverages.

You can then use the NICE guidelines for CVD risk for a reasonable interval of time from the date of your first measurement (the period you need to test at for the risk of CVD to develop) to the date you start testing the following years to determine when your baseline risk for CVD is.
The second step is to determine the time of the time you decide to test. The NICE guidance shows that the amount of time you will need to test from the date of the time you determine the baseline risk is about 1 year.
For the case of a very clear clinical picture, it would be advisable to have tests at 50 years of age, 70 years, or before the age of 70 years if you have ever had a heart attack.
For the case where you have a relatively rare but more persistent episode that is diagnosed as coronary artery disease, the guidelines suggest that it takes three years after screening for either heart attack or angina to get to the target level of high blood pressure to achieve the target for risk of CVD.
If you are at high risk of having a future acute heart attack or angina but are not known to be clinically symptomatic or at risk have a patient who has a chronic angina/brucellosis or chronic heart block without presenting evidence of coronary artery disease, you can postpone having testing for cardiovascular risk until after your assessment of your patient's baseline risk.

Q. What are the main targets of CVD interventions? What interventions should be integrated?
A. There are 7 major targets for CVD that a healthcare professional can set as health professionals have no influence, but if a professional can set the target for their own care, then they can be as successful as possible in achieving their goals. The main targets for CVD are as follows:
1) The highest risk group are those people with a BMI of 30 and/or high LDL-C (2.5), and people with a previous cardiovascular diagnosis of 1 to 3 years; a healthy lifestyle; a well-rested lifestyle, with no smoking; a healthy diet and weight loss.
2) These individuals have 2 NICE guidelines, CVD prevention (3,4) and CVD risk, to help reduce or control these risk factors. CHD is the biggest risk factor for CVD and the main indicator of CVD mortality.
3) A CVD prevention programme in the NHS is the main primary prevention strategy of CVD. Targets on these 3 measures will be implemented and assessed in the 2010 ACC/AHA Task Force Report (Task Force 2010). There can be other targets from those 3 strategies with lower likelihood of success. Targets must be as low but with high confidence.
4) A CVD risk programme (3,4) has a specific target of 30 point-wise improvement over 2 years. Targets need to be as high as possible to allow change and improvement in risk behaviours (diet, exercise and weight control).
5) A good lifestyle advice programme for people who have a CVD risk (diet, alcohol or exercise, for example) would have a target of at least 9 points to improve risk. Targets can be either low or high for a variety of reasons, (for example, having an exercise programme in the past (4,5), lifestyle changes in the past (6) or healthy habits (7).
6) The most common type of evidence suggests that a CVD risk improvement programme should be as high as 2 or 3 points to achieve a high effect. The best results can also be achieved as the result of 2 points reduction (6).
7) In support of the recommendations of IADRC, there is substantial body of evidence that, with very high support (and possibly an increase in awareness), people can achieve their goals within 2 years of initiation (8). This includes people with a BMI of 30 (10), who have one or more NICE guidelines and those with a history of CVD (11,12,13), and those with a previous stroke (14,15).
8) Targeted care of CVD should be based on evidence that there is a 20% reduction in risk for some 24 days to 10 hours of follow-up and 25% drop of risk-taking behaviours.
9) The 2010 Task Force report made recommendations for a CVD prevention programme based on a range of evidence (16). In a study of UK adults with metabolic syndrome (17), those who had a BMI of 30 and/or a history of CVD (2.5) had a 36% lower risk of CVD. A: The majority of CVDs result from a history of unhealthy lifestyle such as having an unhealthy environment, stress, heavy drinking, smoking, or a sedentary life style. The three main types of lifestyle-related CVDs are lifestyle-related coronary heart disease; lifestyle-related hypertension; and lifestyle-related peripheral vascular disease. CVDs are diagnosed when a person has two of the following conditions in the absence of other risk factors or other medical conditions. There is no evidence of a relationship between the presence of these conditions and the development of CVD.
However, if the person has three or more of these conditions, there may be a greater risk of CVD than if only one of the conditions is present. For example, high levels of total cholesterol, high blood pressure, and a family history of heart disease may increase the risk of CVD when someone also has low levels of HDL ('good') cholesterol. In contrast, lifestyle-related CVDs are more likely to be diagnosed when someone has two or more of these conditions.
The main cardiovascular management guidelines for CVD risk management in Australia or New Zealand are the following:
- Age >30 years, and
- Tobacco smoking or dependence (as measured by the National Intensive Tobacco-Free Lifetime Excludes) 30 years for women and 30 years for men, for males 40 years, and for females 40 years
- Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction.
Other CVDs known to have a relationship with smoking include atrial fibrillation, transient ischemic attack, and peripheral artery disease or atherosclerosis from diabetes, obesity, renal disease, renal failure/hepatocolysis, or renal failure, with a family history of CVD, or to a history of smoking with a family history of cardiovascular disease. The following conditions have been identified as an independent predictor of CVD: high blood pressure, cholesterol, hypertension, diabetes, obesity, and smoking cessation. This is one of the reasons why the American Heart Association has recommended that people under 30 be screened for high blood pressure, diabetes for more than 3 years, and smoking cessation for at least a year.
This is also the reason the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE), the part of the health service that manages high-risk patients to a certain point. NICE's role is to examine lifestyle-related CVDs and to suggest treatment and advice to help prevent or lower the incidence of CVD.
- Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction.

What is a risk factor, and how is it classified by the cardiovascular risk assessment tool (CRAFT) tool?
(481) The CRAFT tool divides risk levels into 5 categories:
- No or low-risk: Less than 40% of individuals meet a CRAFT score.
- Low-risk: Risk of incident heart disease of 30 percent or more from the baseline population estimated baseline health profile.
The CRAFT tool allows the determination of an individual's risk level in two ways.
- A medical assessment.
- A clinical assessment.
A medical assessment involves reviewing the medical history of the individual and discussing these factors if a person thinks a risk level is likely to be acceptable.
A clinical assessment, sometimes called a diagnostic evaluation, asks a patient if he or she meets or exceeds a specific set of recommended medical screening criteria, such as the American Academy of Pediatrics standard.
The purpose of this step is to identify the type of risk and to identify the key factors contributing to the risk.
- When considering risk, individuals need a detailed information about their health situation, including:
- Prior treatment of major disease
- Previous treatment for risk factors common to the patient
- Family history of heart disease and stroke
- Physical characteristics that do not make an individual risk.
- A patient should ask multiple questions:
- The reason for the assessment.
- Whether it will have a significant impact on future treatment decisions.
- About the risks and benefits.
- Are there any limitations to the analysis?
For the CRAFT tool (also known as the CECF) use the tool in order to complete the steps:
- You must obtain written consent from the patient to have the data submitted.
- Information obtained will be reviewed and used to provide a baseline measure of cardiometabolic risk.
- The assessment will be followed only after a detailed discussion, informed consent, and detailed review of the results.
- The results of the assessment will be interpreted by a CRAFT expert and a third party professional.
- The results are not included in the medical diagnosis.
- After making decisions about how to manage risk factors, a case presentation/advisory will be reported.
- The results of the assessment will also be considered when making final recommendations for how to manage risk factors.
